questions.question: Question 1: The Rhesus blood group antigen complex is located on which chromosome?
questions.explanation:
The genetic locus for the Rh antigen complex is on the short arm of chromosome 1. RhCcEe and RhD are the two distinct genes located within the Rh locus. The presence of D 
antigen on one or both chromosomes 1, determines heterozygosity or homozygosity respectively.

questions.question:
Question 2: Antigens of which of the following blood group systems do not cause alloimmunization in a 
newborn/fetus?
questions.explanation:
The Lewis antigens do not cause alloimmunization or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn. Alloimmunization/isoimmunisation is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens after 
exposure to genetically different cells or tissues. The Kell blood group system is complex and contains many antigens that are highly 
immunogenic. These antigens are the third most potent, after those of the ABO and Rh blood 
groups, at triggering an immune reaction. Anti-Kell causes severe fetal anemia by suppressing 
fetal RBC synthesis. MNS and Kidd blood types cause alloimmunization. Hemolytic disease of newborn is mild with 
Kidd whereas MNS causes potentially severe anemia. 525 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A pregnant Rh-negative woman presents for her regular antenatal visit. Her Indirect Coombs 
test is negative. When would you give her prophylactic Anti-D?
questions.explanation:
In a non-immunized Rh-negative primigravida, Anti D is given at 28 weeks of gestation. It is also 
given within 72 hours of delivery. Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 
hours of delivery decreases the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent. Additionally, the provision of Anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks of gestation reduces the 
third-trimester alloimmunization rate from approximately 2 percent to 0.1 percent.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis. Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances: • Pregnancy loss due to: • Ectopic pregnancy • Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole • Elective abortion • Fetal death (any trimester) • Procedures: • Amniocentesis • Chorionic villus sampling • Fetal blood sampling • External cephalic version • Delivery • Trauma • Placental abruption • Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 5: Chorionic villus sampling was performed on a G2P1 Rh-negative woman at 10 weeks of 
gestation. What is the dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin that should be administered?
questions.explanation:
The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 g. All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 g of Rh-immune globulin IM in the first 
trimester in the following conditions: • Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion • Ectopic/molar pregnancy • Chorionic villus sampling 526 
Sold by @itachibot Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 g. Generally, a 300 
g dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 g or 1500 international units (IU).

questions.question:
Question 6: An Rh-negative G2P1 mother delivered her Rh-positive baby by cesarean section. Kleihaeur 
Betke test, as shown in the image, was done. Which of the following statements is true 
regarding the test?

options.a: Fetal erythrocytes are the ghost cells
options.c: The reagent used is citric acid

questions.explanation:
The reagent used for the Kleihauer-Betke test is citric acid. Kleihauer-Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test used to detect fetomaternal 
hemorrhage i.e., the approximate volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation. It is 
also known as the acid elution test. The principle behind it is that fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to 
acid elution than hemoglobin A. After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal 
erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” Fetal cells are counted and expressed 
as a percentage of adult cells. Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more 
sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test. Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of 
fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to 
HbF or to the D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence.

questions.question:
Question 7: If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of 
Rh-immunoglobulin calculated is:

options.a: 10 g for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs
options.b: 10 g for every 5 mL of fetal RBCs
options.c: 0.5 g for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood
options.d: 5 g for every 10 mL of fetal whole blood

questions.explanation:
If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of 
Rh-immune globulin calculated is 10 g for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs. 527 
Sold by @itachibot The calculation is done as follows: • 300 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30ml of fetal whole blood. • 50 micrograms of Anti-D can neutralize 2.5 ml of fetal RBCs. The half-life of anti D is 16-24 days. It is administered intramuscularly either in the deltoid or in 
the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

Question 9: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of 
an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.explanation:
MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative 
sensitized mothers. The middle cerebral artery is used as other fetal vessels require a larger insonating angle and 
confers significant measurement error. MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood, 
which permits the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in cases of blood-group 
alloimmunization. If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 
or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced 
amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia. 528 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: In modified Liley's (Queenan) chart, which zone represents a severely affected fetus?
questions.explanation:
A severely affected fetus is represented by zone 3. Liley developed a chart of changing amniotic fluid bilirubin levels (delta OD450) and weeks 
of gestation. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as 
a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm (OD450). However, middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PCV) is non-invasive and more 
accurate than optical density at 450 nm, hence Liley’s chart is no longer used in practice. Liley’s chart has three zones as shown below, delineating the severity of rhesus disease. • Liley’s zone I (low zone) - mild disease. • Liley’s zone II (mid zone) - fetal anemia. • Liley’s zone III (high zone) - severely affected fetus and fetal death is imminent.

questions.question:
Question 11: •ou are performing a Doppler assessment of a fetal middle cerebral artery. What is the 
threshold value of its peak systolic velocity that would prompt you to consider fetal blood 
sampling?
questions.explanation:
Threshold (critical value) of middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity is 1.5 multiples of 
the median (MoM). If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is 
necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion. The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The 
velocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity. In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral 
artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. This method provided 100 
percent sensitivity. 529 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh-negative patient with an antibody titer of 1:32 presents to the clinic at 
30 weeks. A USG reveals features of fetal edema, ascites, and polyhydramnios. Cordocentesis 
was done for fetal blood sampling. At what hematocrit value is intrauterine blood transfusion 
indicated?
questions.explanation:
Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%. The blood for transfusion is usually O negative and cross-matched with the mother's blood. It is 
highly packed to achieve a hematocrit of 75 -80%. Intrauterine transfusions may be done intraperitoneally where blood is absorbed through 
diaphragmatic lymphatics. It may also be done intravascularly through the umbilical vein. The 
segments of the umbilical vein used are the intrahepatic portion or at its insertion into the 
placenta. Complications of intrauterine transfusion include: • Fetal demise • Chorioamnionitis • Placental abruption • Pre-term labor • Bradycardia/tachyarrhythmia • Umbilical cord hematoma

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient presented for an antenatal checkup at 25 weeks of gestation. She had bilateral 
pitting pedal edema and a history of mild headaches. While updating her antenatal card, a 
weight gain of 13 kgs in the past 2 weeks was noted. USG revealed gross fetal hydrops and a 
hyperechoic placenta. Which of the following is not true about the patient's condition?

options.a: It is also known as Ballantyne syndrome
options.b: Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization
options.c: It is associated with elevated liver enzymes
options.d: It is a not a form of pre-eclampsia

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may be 
considered a form of severe pre-eclampsia. Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development of 
maternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It is 
characterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous. The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblastic 
damage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence, 
these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as: • Edema • Hypertension • Proteinuria • Liver enzyme elevation • Headache and visual disturbances. However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirror 
syndrome: • Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration • Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios • The fetus always shows signs of hydrops. 530 
Sold by @itachibot The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops could 
be due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetal 
cystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc. In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severe 
features of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of the 
cause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for the 
remainder of the pregnancy.

Question 14: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient to screen for hydrops fetalis. 
What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
questions.explanation:
The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also 
known as the Halo sign. Other USG signs include: • Ascites • Pleural effusion • Pericardial effusion • Typical position termed as Buddha's position The image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:

Question 15: An Rh-negative patient who did not have access to antenatal care delivered a stillborn fetus as 
shown in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the fetal condition?
questions.explanation:
The pale, oedematous fetus in the image is suggestive of fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is associated 
with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. It often occurs as an effect of iso-immunization in an Rh-negative pregnancy. Other complications 
that may occur are fetal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. 531 
Sold by @itachibot Fetal anemia occurs in the initial stage of iso-immunization. It is associated with polyhydramnios 
and increased placental thickening (hyper-placentosis). An increase in the right atrium size of the 
fetus is seen. Fetal hydrops is usually accompanied by severe anemia. It results in stillbirth or fetal demise soon 
after birth. It is also associated with: • Congestive cardiac failure • Ascites • Pleural effusion • Pericardial effusion • Hepatosplenomegaly. 532 
Sold by @itachibot Hepatic Disorders and Infections in Pregnancy
